question: Question_B_06_(e)
statement:
Consider the triangle \emph{T} in three dimensions with vertices
\emph{(0, 1, 2)}, \emph{(1, 1, 5)} and \emph{(â1, 2, 2)}.

Consider also the plane \emph{P} that contains \emph{T}.

Is \emph{(0, 0, â1)} in the triangle \emph{T}? Justify.
sols:
The answer will be that \emph{(0, 0, 1)} is outside of \emph{T}. There
can be many different ways to show this, and it takes a correct
formulation of a \emph{decisive} criterion and then patience and
carefulness to work till the end.

For the subsequent paragraphs, let us denote
$\vec{OA} = (0, 1, 2), \vec{OB} = (-1, 2, 2), \vec{OC} = (1, 1, 5)$ for
brevity.

This solution explores the parametrization method. This method is
somewhat a more sophisticated but it works beautifully.

Starting from point \emph{A}, we can travel to \emph{B} and \emph{C} by
the vectors

\[\vec{AB} = \vec{OB} - \vec{OA} = (-1,2,2) - (0,1,2) = (-1,1,0)\] and

\[\vec{AC} = \vec{OC} - \vec{OA} = (1,1,5) - (0,1,2) = (1,0,3)\]
respectively.

Therefore, the expressions

\[\vec{OA} + t \vec{AB}\]

and

\[\vec{OA} + s \vec{AC}\]

with $0 \leq s,t \leq 1$, represents all points from A to B and A to C
respectively.

It turns out we can combine them and write:

\[\vec{OA} + t \vec{AB} + s \vec{AC} = (0,1,2) + t(-1,1,0) + s(1,0,3) = (s-t, 1+t, 2+3s)\]

with the \textbf{extra} requirement that $0 \leq s+t \leq 1$ to describe
all points in the triangle \emph{T}.

Now $(s-t, 1+t, 2+3s) = (0, 0, -1)$ implies $s=t=-1$ Thus, it's not in
\emph{T}.

\textbf{Remark 1}: \emph{(0, 0, -1)} is not even a point in the
parallelogram\[(s-t, 1+t, 2+3s)\] with $0 \leq s,t \leq 1$)

\textbf{Remark 2}: The fact that it was solvable for \emph{s} and
\emph{t} shows that the point in the plane \emph{P}. If it weren't in
the plane, e.g. the point \emph{(0, 0, 1)}, it wouldn't be solvable and
some inconsistencies in the linear equations will result.

The answer will be that \emph{(0, 0, -1)} is outside of \emph{T}. There
are many different possible ways to show this, but they all take a
correct formulation of a \emph{decisive} criterion and then patience and
carefulness to work till the end.

For this solution, let's explore some methods using basic geometry. We
will hardly use the concept of vectors, and so for the subsequent
paragraphs, let us denote $A = (0,1,2),$ $B = (-1,2,2),$ $C = (1,1,5)$,
and $D = (0,0,-1)$ for brevity.

This are a few ways to formulate a criterion to determine whether
\emph{D = (0, 0, -1)} is inside or outside \emph{T}. Here we suggest 2
possible criteria.

In both cases, we consider the triangles
$\triangle ABD, \triangle BCD, \triangle CAD$. There are two
qualitatively different pictures for \emph{D} inside or outside
\emph{T}.

\textbf{Need to include the sketch here}

\textbf{Criterion 1 - Comparing Lengths}

If \emph{D} is outside \emph{T}, then at least one of the lengths
\emph{AD}, \emph{BD} or \emph{CD} is strictly greater than the largest
of \emph{AB}, \emph{BC}, \emph{CA}.

Conversely if \emph{D} is inside \emph{T}, then all the lengths
\emph{AD}, \emph{BD} or \emph{CD} is less than or equal to the largest
of \emph{AB}, \emph{BC}, \emph{CA}.

Now, we calculate:

\[AB = |(-1,1,0)| = \sqrt{2}\]

\[BC = |(2,-1,3)| = \sqrt{14}\]

\[CA = |(1,0,3)| = \sqrt{10}\]

But since

\[DC = |(1,1,6)| = \sqrt{38}\], \emph{D} is outside of \emph{T}.

\textbf{Criterion 2 - Compare Areas}

If \emph{D} is outside \emph{T}, then the sum of areas of
$\triangle ABD, \triangle BCD, \triangle CAD$ is strictly greater than
that of $\triangle ABC$

Conversely if \emph{D} is inside \emph{T}, then equality holds instead.

We already knew that area of $T = \triangle ABC$ is $\sqrt{19}/2$. Let's
calculate the area of $\triangle BCD$

\begin{align*}
\text{Area}(\triangle BCD)&= \frac{1}{2} \left|\vec{BD} \times \vec{CD} \right|\\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left|(-1,2,3) \times (1,1,6) \right|\\
&= \frac{1}{2} |(9,9,-3)|\\
&= \frac{3\sqrt{19}}{2}
\end{align*}

So, without calculating the other areas, we can be sure that \emph{D} is
outside of \emph{T}.

\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2010/Question B6 (d)}{
Part (d)} already shows that \emph{(0, 0, -1)} is in \emph{P} which
contains \emph{T}. So \emph{(0, 0, -1)} is in the same plane as the
vertices of the triangle \emph{T}.

From here, two of the possible routes would be to:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
i) express every point in \emph{T} by a parametrization to check whether
\emph{(0, 0, -1)} is in \emph{T}
\end{description}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
ii) sketch both pictures when \emph{(0, 0, -1)} is inside or outside
\emph{T}, then deduce a geometric criterion from the picture
\end{description}

For i), one needs to think of one of the vertices as a \emph{base} point
and \emph{walk} to a point inside \emph{T} by following the 2 directions
toward the other two vertices.

For ii), one can think of the paper being written on to be the plane
\emph{P}, then sketch the vertices of \emph{T} as you would for points
in 2 dimensional space. Do not assume any particular order of the
vertices or relative positions.

After the sketch, one needs to construct geometrical figures relating
the point \emph{(0, 0, -1)} to the vertices of the triangle \emph{T}.
For instance, one can consider triangles with this new point as a
vertex.
